1121466828990160899.text: The thing about algorithmic moderation is that it is just pattern matching; it doesn't have our underlying model of the world. Usually that is embarrassing or problematic, but sometimes it reveals things we can't see.

1121464810703675392.text: In other words: as I read it, the source isn't so much talking about the overt racism of the Steve Kings or Donald Trumps of the world, but the scary fact that "normal" GOP politicians are close enough to it that computers would produce false positive matches

1121463755550941184.text: The subtler (and maybe scarier) point is that "mainstream" GOPers would be "incorrectly" flagged because it's now just hard to distinguish between right orthodoxy and viewpoints that society deems truly heinous. Whoops!

1121462832032358400.text: The more straightforward point is that there are actual Nazis and white supremacists who the filter would be correct to tag, EXCEPT they are GOP politicians or leaders

1121462432885608448.text: I should note, the article (and its source) are making a subtler point than my glib gloss. There are two related-but-distinct factors here

1113576210754416641.text: That is to say, all of the benefits of HTTPS come from the properties of end-to-end encryption. If the adversary is willing and able to compromise either end, those benefits go away.

1113575695475671040.text: Whether the newly-observed browser-level blocks are corporate or governmental, they represent another escalation. In a sense, it's a game-over level of capturing the endpoint. Not good.

1113575270190022656.text: A few years ago, China escalated its efforts to censor Github with a sophisticated new man-in-the-middle attack that also relied on unencrypted HTTP, but on arbitrary sites inside the countryhttps://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2015/04/meet-great-cannon-the-man-in-the-middle-weapon-china-used-on-github/ …

1113574275334713344.text: That kind of full site block, forced by HTTPS adoption, has played out a number of times—and has largely been untenable. Github in China, Wikipedia in Russia, Google Reader in Iran, Medium in Malaysia.

1113573608448720896.text: One of the compelling arguments for HTTPS is that it forces censors to be much more visible and heavy-handed, blocking whole domains instead of individual pages. I've written about that previously:https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2016/01/mediums-sitewide-encryption-confronts-censorship-malaysia …

1113573112401076224.text: Yikes: it's not confirmed to be governmental, but this kind of browser-level censorship represents a pretty significant escalation from traditional network-level effortshttps://www.theverge.com/2019/4/3/18294030/tencent-xiaomi-china-censorship-browser-block-github-page-worker-grievances …

6/ I'm as excited as anyone for a "New Life For Old Classics" the NY Times describes: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/29/books/copyright-extension-literature-public-domain.html …

But I'm even more excited that another year of our collective cultural heritage is returned to the commons, no longer held captive in the name of of those old classics.

1080191109836492800.text: 5/ Yes, we should celebrate getting "Stopping By Woods on a Snowy Evening" and "Safety Last," and all those famous works! But the most exciting part is that as the Sonny Bono Firewall marches forward, thousands upon thousands of *unknown* works can be digitized and rediscovered.pic.twitter.com/W5ZhAqQeuJ

1080191108930564097.text: 4/ So many of the exciting and innovative uses of the public domain today rely on (a) lots and lots of works and (b) near certainty about their copyright status. The effect has been that 1923 was a firewall, with certainty on one side and intolerable risk on the other.

1080191108125212674.text: 3/ The works that we're celebrating as they enter the US public domain today, then, are a teeny tiny portion of the things that were written, drawn, recorded, or composed in 1923. BUT—

1080191107240210434.text: 2/  Already when we copyright nerds talk about partying like it's 1923, we're starting with a tiny fraction. But it gets worse: the vast majority of even copyrighted works would not have been profitable by the 1950s—so many rose into the public domain then!

1080191106208485376.text: 1/ In 1923—unlike today—the vast majority of human expression was never subject to copyright, because new works had to bear proper notice and be duly registered

1080191105386328065.text: I'd like to make a point about copyright and the commons that I haven't seen other celebrants of this wonderful Public Domain Day mention yet
